articles.headline: As Federal Cash Flows to Unions, Democrats Hope to Reap the Rewards
articles.snippet: In places like West Virginia, money from three major laws passed by Congress is pouring into the alternative energy industry and other projects. “I think it’s a renaissance for the labor movement,” said one union official.
articles.abstract: In places like West Virginia, money from three major laws passed by Congress is pouring into the alternative energy industry and other projects. “I think it’s a renaissance for the labor movement,” said one union official.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, W.Va. — In the mid-1970s, when Mark Raddish wasn’t more than 11 years old, his coal-mining grandfather picked him up from a mining camp and took him a thousand feet underground, to the cold darkness beneath West Virginia. There, he imparted a lesson.

articles.headline: Electric Vehicles Could Match Gasoline Cars on Price This Year
articles.snippet: Competition, government incentives and falling raw material prices are making battery-powered cars more affordable sooner than expected.
articles.abstract: Competition, government incentives and falling raw material prices are making battery-powered cars more affordable sooner than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: More quickly than seemed possible a few months ago, sticker prices for electric vehicles are falling closer to the point where they could soon be on a par with gasoline cars.

articles.headline: U.S. Shoots Down High-Altitude Object Over Alaska
articles.snippet: The incident comes less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic during a diplomatic crisis.
articles.abstract: The incident comes less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic during a diplomatic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said it shot down an unidentified object over frozen waters around Alaska on Friday at the order of President Biden, less than a week after a U.S. fighter jet brought down a Chinese spy balloon over the Atlantic in an episode that increased tensions between Washington and Beijing.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong

articles.headline: DeSantis Declares Victory as Disney Is Stripped of Some 56-Year-Old Perks
articles.snippet: The Legislature approved a bill that restricts the autonomy of Florida’s largest private employer over a fight involving the teaching of sexual orientation and gender identity.
articles.abstract: The Legislature approved a bill that restricts the autonomy of Florida’s largest private employer over a fight involving the teaching of sexual orientation and gender identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida gained control on Friday of the board that oversees development at Walt Disney World, a move that restricts the autonomy of Disney, the state’s largest private employer, over its theme-park complex and strips some perks enjoyed by the company for 56 years.

articles.headline: Russia Fires Major Missile Barrage at Ukraine as Combat Intensifies
articles.snippet: The first major aerial bombardment in weeks targeted cities across Ukraine, as President Volodymyr Zelensky returned home from a trip across Europe to press for more arms.
articles.abstract: The first major aerial bombardment in weeks targeted cities across Ukraine, as President Volodymyr Zelensky returned home from a trip across Europe to press for more arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia targeted Ukraine’s already battered infrastructure with more than 100 drones, rockets and missiles on Friday, raining explosives on cities around the country as President Volodymyr Zelensky returned from a three-day trip across Europe to ask Ukraine’s allies to send more weapons, and faster.

articles.headline: Why Adani’s $100 Billion Loss Hasn’t Tanked India’s Markets
articles.snippet: The steadfastness of India’s economy attests to the size and seeming strength of the country’s broader business landscape.
articles.abstract: The steadfastness of India’s economy attests to the size and seeming strength of the country’s broader business landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: When shares of the Adani Group, until recently India’s largest conglomerate, began their free fall late last month, shedding more than $100 billion in days, some observers worried that the collapse could bring down the country’s capital markets, and with them the Indian economy.

articles.headline: When It’s Easy to Be a Landlord, No One Wants to Sell
articles.snippet: Locked in at historically low interest rates. Platforms that make managing rentals a breeze. Homeowners have little incentive to put a house on the market.
articles.abstract: Locked in at historically low interest rates. Platforms that make managing rentals a breeze. Homeowners have little incentive to put a house on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’m part of the problem.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Why Are You Seeing So Many Bad Digital Ads Now?
articles.snippet: Scrolling past ads has rarely been enjoyable. But in recent months, people say the experience seems so much worse.
articles.abstract: Scrolling past ads has rarely been enjoyable. But in recent months, people say the experience seems so much worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Portia Kapraun has always seen unwelcome ads on Twitter, usually from major brands pitching her luxury jewelry or vehicles that she, as a librarian in Indiana, could not afford.

articles.headline: As Anger Swells Over Quake, Turkey Detains Building Contractors
articles.snippet: As the death toll in Turkey and Syria passed 28,000, Ankara was coming under growing criticism for its slow response and tolerance of shoddy construction.
articles.abstract: As the death toll in Turkey and Syria passed 28,000, Ankara was coming under growing criticism for its slow response and tolerance of shoddy construction.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADIYAMAN, Turkey — Turkish officials on Saturday began detaining dozens of contractors they blamed for some of the building collapses in Monday’s devastating earthquake, as anger swelled over the government’s slow rescue effort and the death toll in the country surpassed 24,000.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad, Raja Abdulrahim, Safak Timur, Steven Erlanger and Gulsin Harman

articles.headline: U.S. Jet Shoots Down Flying Object Over Canada
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he and President Biden had ordered the object violating Canadian airspace to be taken down, a day after another object was shot out of the sky near Alaska.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he and President Biden had ordered the object violating Canadian airspace to be taken down, a day after another object was shot out of the sky near Alaska.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American fighter jet, acting on the orders of President Biden and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, shot down another unidentified flying object on Saturday, Canadian and American officials said, in the latest installment of the drama playing out in the skies of North America.

articles.headline: Wanted: Interns Who Can Make TikTok Hits
articles.snippet: The hot new internship for college students is creating TikTok content for brands hawking jewelry, ice cream, sunflower seeds and more.
articles.abstract: The hot new internship for college students is creating TikTok content for brands hawking jewelry, ice cream, sunflower seeds and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mary Clare Lacke, a 20-year-old student at the University of Missouri, interned at Claire’s last summer, one of her tasks was to help the teen accessories company with its nascent TikTok account. It didn’t take long for her to produce a hit — though it wasn’t one that the retailer saw coming.

articles.headline: A Yale Professor Suggested Mass Suicide for Old People in Japan. What Did He Mean?
articles.snippet: Yusuke Narita says he is mainly addressing a growing effort to revamp Japan’s age-based hierarchies. Still, he has pushed the country’s hottest button.
articles.abstract: Yusuke Narita says he is mainly addressing a growing effort to revamp Japan’s age-based hierarchies. Still, he has pushed the country’s hottest button.
articles.lead_paragraph: His pronouncements could hardly sound more drastic.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida

articles.headline: They Are Russians Fighting Against Their Homeland. Here’s Why.
articles.snippet: In the Free Russia Legion, soldiers repelled by Vladimir Putin’s invasion have taken arms against their home country, engaged in some of the most heated fighting in the war.
articles.abstract: In the Free Russia Legion, soldiers repelled by Vladimir Putin’s invasion have taken arms against their home country, engaged in some of the most heated fighting in the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: The soldier knelt in the snow, aimed a rocket launcher and fired in the direction of Russian troops positioned about a mile away. He was set up at a Ukrainian firing position, and looked just like the other Ukrainian troops fighting south of the city of Bakhmut in one of the most brutal theaters of the war.

articles.headline: Amnesty in Turkey for Construction Violations Is Scrutinized After Quake
articles.snippet: Survivors and building experts say poor construction most likely exacerbated the scale of the earthquake’s destruction, as the death toll in Turkey and Syria surpassed 33,000 people.
articles.abstract: Survivors and building experts say poor construction most likely exacerbated the scale of the earthquake’s destruction, as the death toll in Turkey and Syria surpassed 33,000 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail in 2019, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey praised legislation that his political party had pushed through allowing property owners to have construction violations forgiven without bringing their buildings up to code.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Gulsin Harman and Safak Timur

articles.headline: Across Paris, an Invader Unleashes His Art
articles.snippet: Mosaics by a street artist, who calls himself “Invader,” have become part of the fabric of the city. They are everywhere — if you look for them.
articles.abstract: Mosaics by a street artist, who calls himself “Invader,” have become part of the fabric of the city. They are everywhere — if you look for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It all began down a narrow cobblestone road near Place de la Bastille.

articles.headline: What’s Going On Up There? Theories but No Answers in Shootdowns of Mystery Craft.
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Canada are investigating three unidentified flying objects shot down over North America in the past three days. Militaries have adjusted radars to try to spot more incursions.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Canada are investigating three unidentified flying objects shot down over North America in the past three days. Militaries have adjusted radars to try to spot more incursions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the truth is out there, it certainly is not apparent yet.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Why Mississippi, a Covid Hot Spot, Left Millions in Pandemic Aid Unspent
articles.snippet: Stop-and-go federal funding floods public health agencies with cash during crises but starves them of funds afterward. The coronavirus pandemic shows the pitfalls of that approach.
articles.abstract: Stop-and-go federal funding floods public health agencies with cash during crises but starves them of funds afterward. The coronavirus pandemic shows the pitfalls of that approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — When the coronavirus first scythed through the nation in early 2020, few places needed help fighting it more than Scott County, Miss., a rural patch of chicken processing plants and pine forests an hour east of the state capital, Jackson.

articles.headline: Happiness or Success? Salesforce’s Marc Benioff Doesn’t Want to Choose.
articles.snippet: The chief executive, under pressure from activist investors, seeks to do well and do good — but his options are narrowing.
articles.abstract: The chief executive, under pressure from activist investors, seeks to do well and do good — but his options are narrowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many years ago, Thich Nhat Hanh, the Buddhist monk and spiritual leader, posed a question to Marc Benioff, the co-founder and chief executive of Salesforce.

articles.headline: Beyond Silicon Valley, Spending on Technology Is Resilient
articles.snippet: Despite an uncertain outlook, corporations plan to continue investing in their digital projects — a source of stability for the economy.
articles.abstract: Despite an uncertain outlook, corporations plan to continue investing in their digital projects — a source of stability for the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson Controls traces its origin to the late 19th century in Wisconsin, where a clever teacher and inventor named Warren Johnson designed an early thermostat to turn the heat on or off in his classroom.

articles.headline: The College Board’s Rocky Path, Through Florida, to the A.P. Black Studies Course
articles.snippet: The nonprofit met with Governor DeSantis’s state officials, who asked whether the course was “trying to advance Black Panther thinking.”
articles.abstract: The nonprofit met with Governor DeSantis’s state officials, who asked whether the course was “trying to advance Black Panther thinking.”
articles.lead_paragraph: On the second night of Black History Month, a sparkling crowd of academics and teachers gathered at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture to celebrate the unveiling of the first ever Advanced Placement course in African American studies.
articles.byline: By Anemona Hartocollis, Dana Goldstein and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: China’s Top Airship Scientist Promoted Program to Watch the World From Above
articles.snippet: Corporate records and media reports reveal an airship scientist at the center of China’s high-altitude balloon program. Companies he has founded were among those targeted by Washington.
articles.abstract: Corporate records and media reports reveal an airship scientist at the center of China’s high-altitude balloon program. Companies he has founded were among those targeted by Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2019, years before a hulking high-altitude Chinese balloon floated across the United States and caused widespread alarm, one of China’s top aeronautics scientists made a proud announcement that received little attention back then: His team had launched an airship more than 60,000 feet into the air and sent it sailing around most of the globe, including across North America.

articles.headline: Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul Sparks Huge Protests in Israel
articles.snippet: As Benjamin Netanyahu’s government pressed ahead with plans to limit judicial influence, Israelis thronged to unusually large rallies.
articles.abstract: As Benjamin Netanyahu’s government pressed ahead with plans to limit judicial influence, Israelis thronged to unusually large rallies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A battle over the future of Israel’s judiciary — perceived by many as a fight for the soul of Israel’s democracy — grew more fraught and fractious on Monday as roughly 100,000 protesters from across the country filled the streets outside Parliament in Jerusalem in one of the biggest-ever demonstrations in the city.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: They Were Told Their Building Was Earthquake Safe. It Collapsed Anyway.
articles.snippet: Some structures promoted as being built to modern seismic codes did not withstand the quake in Turkey. One upscale tower that fell may have had a design flaw, engineers said.
articles.abstract: Some structures promoted as being built to modern seismic codes did not withstand the quake in Turkey. One upscale tower that fell may have had a design flaw, engineers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The upscale three-year-old housing complex of Asur in the Turkish city of Malatya, replete with chandeliers and marble floors, promised to be earthquake safe, built with the best materials to modern seismic codes. Residents in the middle-class neighborhood paid more for those assurances.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Ceylan Yeginsu
